docs.lead_paragraph: On Jan. 27, 2010, President Obama presented his first State of the Union address, promising to focus intently on jobs and the economy, the issues of most immediate concern to the nation.

headline.main: Analyzing President Obama's First State of the Union Address

docs.snippet: On Jan. 27, 2010, President Obama presented his first State of the Union address, promising to focus intently on jobs and the economy, the issues of most immediate concern to the nation.

docs.lead_paragraph: Adam Nagourney, Jeff Zeleny, Helene Cooper and David Sanger offer their views on President Obama's State of the Union.
docs.abstract: Correspondents offer their takes on President Obama's speech.
docs.snippet: Correspondents offer their takes on President Obama's speech.

docs.lead_paragraph: In excerpts of his State of the Union speech released this evening, Mr. Obama paints a grim picture of the nation's economic challenges and the dire state of health care costs.

headline.main: Obama to Warn of Consequences of Inaction on Health Care

docs.abstract: "By the time I'm finished speaking tonight, more Americans will have lost their health insurance," the president plans to say tonight.
docs.snippet: "By the time I'm finished speaking tonight, more Americans will have lost their health insurance," the president plans to say tonight.

docs.lead_paragraph: Not even two hours before President Obama was to arrive at the Capitol to give his State of the Union speech, House Republicans were not letting up the pressure one bit. In a letter to the president, they accused him of carrying out secretive negotiations on health care legislation (PDF) and urged him to renounce any further backroom deals.
docs.abstract: Just hours before the State of the Union speech, Republicans accused President Obama of turning the White House into 'a hub of backroom deals.'
docs.snippet: Just hours before the State of the Union speech, Republicans accused President Obama of turning the White House into 'a hub of backroom deals.'

headline.main: House Could Pass a Revised Senate Bill, Pelosi Says

docs.abstract: Congress could move forward with the legislation on two tracks, negotiating a sweeping overhaul while also developing a pared-back bill, the speaker said.
docs.snippet: Congress could move forward with the legislation on two tracks, negotiating a sweeping overhaul while also developing a pared-back bill, the speaker said.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Memorable, Unusual Moment | 10:38 p.m. David Kirkpatrick notes a rare moment of confrontation. As Mr. Obama criticized the recent ruling on campaign finance, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. appeared to correct him.(The justice's reaction is captured on YouTube.)
docs.abstract: Live updates of President Obama's first State of the Union address and reaction throughout the evening.
docs.snippet: Live updates of President Obama's first State of the Union address and reaction throughout the evening.

docs.lead_paragraph: As negotiations on major health care legislation went down to the wire last month, Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, won a lot of attention as the 60th member of the Democratic caucus to commit to voting for the bill.

headline.main: Nelson Planned to Insist on Tighter Abortion Restrictions

docs.abstract: Senator Ben Nelson tells an interviewer that he had intended to withhold his vote for final health care legislation unless more restrictive abortion language was included.
docs.snippet: Senator Ben Nelson tells an interviewer that he had intended to withhold his vote for final health care legislation unless more restrictive abortion language was included.

docs.lead_paragraph: Theology can make for confusing politics, especially in partisan Washington.

headline.main: Catholic Bishops Urge Congress Not to Abandon Overhaul

docs.abstract: "Now is not the time to abandon this task," the bishops said on Wednesday.
docs.snippet: "Now is not the time to abandon this task," the bishops said on Wednesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: The State of the Union address is less than six hours away, and President Obama and his aides are still putting final touches on the speech, but the White House has provided a set of talking points to Capitol Hill that outlines the central themes he intends to touch upon.
docs.abstract: The White House has circulated a set of talking points for tonight's message to be distributed.
docs.snippet: The White House has circulated a set of talking points for tonight's message to be distributed.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a conference call today with Congressional staff, the White House communications director, Dan Pfeiffer, said that President Obama would reiterate his commitment to a comprehensive overhaul of the nation's health care system in his State of the Union address on Wednesday night.

headline.main: Obama to Reaffirm Commitment to an Overhaul

docs.abstract: President Obama will reiterate his support for comprehensive legislation in the State of the Union speech, the White House told Congressional staff on Wednesday.
docs.snippet: President Obama will reiterate his support for comprehensive legislation in the State of the Union speech, the White House told Congressional staff on Wednesday.
